newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Raging inferno kills 39 on Hong Kong golden mile.
newsitem.headline: Raging inferno kills 39 on Hong Kong golden mile.

text.p: Fire engulfed a 16-floor shop and office block in a bustling Hong Kong tourist district, killing almost 40 people and injuring scores of others in the territory's worst building blaze on record.
The inferno flared up on Wednesday evening and raged through the night, gutting seven floors. Some 300 firemen and 50 fire took almost 24 hours to quell the blaze.
The confirmed death toll on Thursday reached 39, including one fireman, fire chief Peter Cheung said.

"We're still trying to identify bodies and relate those reported missing to those we already know have been killed but whose bodies have not yet been identified," Chris Patten, governor of the British colony, told its Legislative Council.
Officials said 81 were injured and more than 110 rescued. Of the injured, 46 were still in hospital.
Cheung said he had received reports that welding work had been under way in the building's elevator area, on the ground floor where a Chinese arts and crafts store was located.
"An eye witness claimed that welding work was in progress in one of the lift shafts...and that a spark from the welding ignited combustibles at the bottom of the shafts," he said.
The fire spread quickly from the ground right up to the top floors, he added. Investigations were continuing, he stressed.
The closed design of the department store at the bottom of the Garley Building on Nathan Road, Kowloon, was believed to be a big factor in the fast spread of the fire.
The situation was worsened by the lack of an up-to-date fire protection system in the building, Cheung added. Many older buildings in Hong Kong have few, if any, anti-fire devices.
People trapped behind sealed windows on Wednesday night ripped off burning clothes, while others scrambled to safety.
A plume of flame lit up the sky above Hong Kong harbour but later gave way to a black cloud of smoke that hung over the building on the "golden mile" of the Kowloon tourist district.
In dramatic scenes, firefighters plucked survivors from the block, a maze of small offices, shops and workshops, and some were winched off the blazing roof by helicopter.
The fire rapidly engulfed the first four storeys of the building before racing up the lift shaft to the top three.
Smoke blanked out the vision of daring helicopter pilots who flew dangerous missions over rooftops to winch away survivors.
Others jumped from window ledges on to rescue ladders and some scrambled on to air conditioners, observed helplessly by friends and relatives far below in the crowded street.
One of the dead was a fireman killed while battling the blaze. Liu Chi-ho, 40, plunged down a lift shaft.

Another man fell from the building in a rush to escape. Witnesses said they saw him climb from a window and cling to an air conditioner which gave way and sent him tumbling several storeys onto a canopy, where he lay crumpled and still.
Officials said 17 of the charred bodies were found on the 15th floor on Thursday morning.
"This was the most serious (tower block) fire and the one with the most number of deaths and injuries in the past 100 years," Cheung said.
Hong Kong's worst fire on record was in 1918 when 600 people were killed and 400 injured in a blaze at the Happy Valley Racecourse on Hong Kong Island.
A disaster in 1947 killed 149 people when a ship burned in the harbour. In 1953 a Christmas blaze killed an unknown number of people in a squatter village and left 60,000 homeless.
Officials sounded alarm bells about building safety, an issue of protracted debate in the densely populated territory.
Patten visited the spot and later pressed for the speedy passage of legislation to tighten fire regulations. Many older buildings have few, if any, anti-fire devices.
Britain's Queen Elizabeth and Foreign Secretary Malcolm Rifkind sent messages of condolence to Patten on Thursday.
